item.title: India Eyes US Trade Deal by July Though Challenges Remain
item.description: India and the US are keen to clinch an early trade deal before a July 9 deadline when higher US tariffs are set to kick in, but challenges remain, an Indian official familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: Farmers harvest rice saplings at a paddy field in Panipat, India.

item.title: SNB Rate Seen Stuck at Zero This Year After Last Week’s Cut
item.description: The Swiss National Bank probably won’t act this year on its threat of cutting borrowing costs to below zero, according to a majority of economists.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright, Harumi Ichikura

media:content.media:description: The Swiss National Bank in Bern, Switzerland.

item.title: Hungary Is Set to Hold Interest Rates as Price Curbs Fall Short
item.description: Hungary’s central bank is likely to keep its key interest rate unchanged for a ninth month, holding steady amid mounting geopolitical risks and persistently high inflation expectations.
item.dc:creator: Zoltan Simon, Marton Kasnyik

item.title: Japan’s Akazawa Says Still Working on Date for Next Trade Talks
item.description: Japan and the US are still working on setting the timing for the next round of cabinet-level trade talks, Japan’s point person for the negotiations said, as the deadline for a deal to avert another hike in tariffs nears.
item.dc:creator: Brian Fowler

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa

item.title: South Korea’s Trade Chief Seeks Tariff Relief in First US Talks
item.description: South Korea reiterated its call to be exempted from US tariffs including duties affecting key industries such as cars and steel, Trade Minister Yeo Han-koo said after his first meeting with US counterparts since taking up his position.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

media:content.media:description: Yeo Han-koo

item.title: Australia Must Choose Defense or Social Spending, Rabobank Says
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Malaysia to Boost Venture Capital With Tax Incentives
item.description: Malaysia is dangling new tax incentives to investors to boost its venture capital industry, according to Second Finance Minister Amir Hamzah Azizan.
item.dc:creator: Kok Leong Chan

item.title: China Expands Its Coal Exports and Shrinks Imports Due to Glut
item.description: China’s coal glut is resulting in an increasing number of unwanted cargoes being offered abroad.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Kathy Chen

item.title: Korean Consumer Confidence Jumps to 4-Year High on Stimulus Hope
item.description: South Korea’s consumer confidence rose to the highest in four years as easing domestic political uncertainty, fresh fiscal stimulus and hopes for pro-growth policies under the new administration buoyed sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee

item.title: Canada’s Defense Pledges Mean More Borrowing, Watchdog Says
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney’s surprise announcement that Canada would spend 2% of gross domestic product on defense this fiscal year is a recipe for even deeper deficits, the parliamentary budget officer said.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Seal

media:content.media:description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney with Chief of the Defence Staff Gen. Carignan, left, and Minister of National Defence David McGuinty tour Fort York Armoury in Toronto on June 9.

item.title: UK Welcomes £40 Billion Amazon Investment Plan in Warehouses
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer welcomed a three-year program by Amazon.com Inc. to invest £40 billion ($54 billion) in the British economy over the next three years, including opening four new warehouses.
item.dc:creator: Freya Jones

item.title: Trump Tariff Deadline Spurs Asia Export Surge, Wider Trade Gaps
item.description: The US trade deficit with Asia is widening as importers stock up ahead of President Donald Trump’s “reciprocal” tariffs deadline.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Containers are offloaded from the Sinar Sanur cargo ship at the Tan Vu Terminal, operated by Vietnam Maritime Corp., at Haiphong Port in Haiphong, Vietnam, on Wednesday, Jan. 15, 2025. Vietnam Maritime, the state-owned shipping, logistics and seaports company previously known as Vietnam National Shipping Lines or Vinalines, plans to expand its fleet by 20% annually in the next five years,

item.title: Federal Reserve to Eliminate Reputation Risk in Bank Exams
item.description: The Federal Reserve said Monday it will no longer consider reputation risk as part of its bank exams, following calls from some bank groups and Republican lawmakers to end a practice critics have viewed as unfair.
item.dc:creator: Katanga Johnson

media:content.media:description: Joggers pass the Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Tuesday, Aug. 18, 2020. In addition to helping rescue the U.S. economy amid the coronavirus pandemic, Fed Chair Jerome Powell and colleagues also spent 2020 finishing up the central bank’s first-ever review of how it pursues the goals of maximum employment and price stability set for it by Congress.

item.title: IMF Approves $1.3 Billion for Bangladesh as Reforms Advance
item.description: The International Monetary Fund’s executive board has approved a total of $1.3 billion in funding for Bangladesh as part of the ongoing loan program, as the South Asian country pushes ahead with currency and tax reforms.
item.dc:creator: Arun Devnath

media:content.media:description: Dhaka, Bangladesh

item.title: Angola Gets Budget Relief From Oil Gains on Middle East Tension
item.description: Angola may meet its 2025 budget goals without major spending cuts if the oil price remains around $70 where it was benchmarked at, Minister of State for Economic Coordination Jose de Lima Massano said.
item.dc:creator: Candido Mendes

media:content.media:description: A Sonangol refinery in Luanda, Angola.

item.title: Argentina Economy Grows Less Than Expected as Imports Surge
item.description: Argentina’s economy grew less than expected in the first quarter of 2025 as a pickup in imports along with declines in exports and government spending tempered the South American nation’s recovery.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Commuters near Constitucion train station during a nationwide strike in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on Thursday, April 10, 2025. Argentina's largest umbrella labor union, the General Confederation of Labor (CGT), is holding a national strike to protest President Javier Milei's austerity measures, the third major strike since he took office.

item.title: Powell Headed for Congressional Grilling Over Fed’s Rate Hold
item.description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell will have two chances this week to explain to lawmakers why he and most of his fellow policymakers seem resolved to continue holding interest rates steady at least until September, ignoring President Donald Trump’s persistent calls to lower borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell speaks after an FOMC meeting on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, on June 18.

item.title: US Remains in Talks on $500 Million for Angola Rail Corridor
item.description: The US International Development Finance Corp. is still finalizing more than $500 million in financing for the Lobito corridor, a railway project that will haul critical minerals from central Africa’s copper belt to an Atlantic port in Angola.
item.dc:creator: Candido Mendes

item.title: Goolsbee Says Fed Can Cut Rates If Tariff Inflation Doesn’t Come
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago President Austan Goolsbee said the central bank could resume interest-rate cuts if the inflation hit from tariffs remains subdued, without weighing in on the exact timing of such a move.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: President and CEO of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago Austan Goolsbee

item.title: Ireland Warns Thousands of Jobs at Risk From Pharma Tariffs
item.description: Ireland plans to use its budget cushion to pump money into infrastructure to protect competitiveness as global trade turmoil and tariffs threaten thousands of jobs in the multinational hub.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher, Laura Noonan, Stephen Carroll

media:content.media:description: Paschal Donohoe speaks during Bloomberg’s Future of Finance in Ireland event in Dublin, on June 23. Photographer: Dean O'Brien/Bloomberg

item.title: Fed’s Bowman Says ‘Time Has Come’ to Reform Key Capital Rule
item.description: Federal Reserve Vice Chair for Supervision Michelle Bowman warned the current approach to leverage ratio requirements has led to unintended consequences in the market while adding she could support lowering interest rates as soon as July.
item.dc:creator: Katanga Johnson, Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Vice chair for supervision at the US Federal Reserve Michelle Bowman

item.title: BOE Chief Rejects Reform UK’s Plan to End Interest on Reserves
item.description: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey said Reform UK’s plans to end interest payments on central bank reserves would do little to raise revenue and potentially slow down the pace of lending.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Andrew Bailey

item.title: Nagel Says ECB Can’t Commit on Rates Given High Uncertainty
item.description: The European Central Bank shouldn’t commit to a certain interest-rate path, given how US trade policy and the situation in the Middle East are clouding the outlook, according to Governing Council member Joachim Nagel.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the European Central Bank in Frankfurt.

item.title: US Home Resales Stay Sluggish on Affordability Constraints
item.description: US previously owned home sales rose slightly in May to a still-sluggish pace that continues to show a housing market constrained by poor affordability.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: Homes in Hercules, California.

item.title: Lagarde Reiterates ECB Well Placed But Monitoring Oil Swings
item.description: The European Central Bank is well placed to tackle “exceptionally high” uncertainty but will closely watch gyrations in commodities markets as tensions in the Middle East flare, President Christine Lagarde said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde

item.title: US Manufacturing Expands While Inflation Measures Accelerate
item.description: US manufacturing grew at a steady pace so far in June, partly reflecting stronger employment growth, while two measures of inflation accelerated to the highest levels since July 2022.

media:content.media:description: A employee inspects a tire at a bicycles production facility in Manning, South Carolina.

item.title: Global Economy, Resilient to Tariffs, Faces New Mideast Storm
item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston. Today we’re looking at the latest threat to wreck the global economic expansion. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

item.title: Angolan President Urges US Firms to Invest Beyond Oil, Minerals
item.description: Angolan President Joao Lourenco called on US companies to expand their investments in Africa beyond traditional oil and mineral extraction to industries such as automobiles, shipbuilding, tourism, cement and steel.
item.dc:creator: Candido Mendes, Jennifer Zabasajja

media:content.media:description: Angolan president Joao Lourenco

item.title: What Mike Tyson and the Bond Market Can Teach Trump on Debt
item.description: Treasury buyers will be the ultimate arbiters on whether MAGA math adds up.
item.dc:creator: Tom Orlik

item.title: Singapore Inflation Seen to Quicken as Conflict Spurs Oil Prices
item.description: Singapore’s key inflation gauge slowed in May though it will likely accelerate in the coming months as the attack on Iran spurs global crude costs higher.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Li
